CIGE InsightsConclusion: Collaborative Degrees and 
Comprehensive Internationalization
In the international education field, joint and dual degrees are a familiar concept; there is gen-
eral consensus on basic definitions, and a common understanding of the core elements of such 
programs. Working through the quantitative and qualitative components of this study, how -
ever, revealed the complexity and nuances that lie beneath what initially seems like a fairly 
straightforward idea, and the myriad forms these programs take in practice.
In terms of implications for institutions as they consider whether and how to enter the inter -
national collaborative degree arena, perhaps the most important take-away from this study is 
that JDDPs are like fingerprints; they are recognizable as a category, but no two are exactly alike . Certainly, it is possible to develop a general template for MOUs, for example, imple

exactly alike . Certainly, it is possible to develop a general template for MOUs, for example, implement 
a common financial model across programs, and anticipate some challenges based on others‚Äô 
experiences. However, the details‚Äîparticularly in terms of academics and curriculum‚Äîas well 
as the particular challenges that will inevitably arise, are specific to each individual program. Moreover, as conditions shift and programs evolve, new issues, challenges, and decision points emerge, requiring ongoing attention and adaptation.
Given this reality, institutions should approach JDDPs with the clear understanding that sub -
stantial work and resources will be required‚Äîboth at the outset and in order to maintain the 
program over time. As cited by respondents and explored in various sections of this report, existing academic policies (e.g., related to credit transfer, double counting of course work, gen-
eral education, and residency requirements), budgetary realities and tolerance for fi

rse work, gen-
eral education, and residency requirements), budgetary realities and tolerance for financial 
uncertainty, and faculty and staff enthusiasm and engagement, among other institutional fac-tors, should inform decisions about whether it makes sense to pursue international collabora -
tive degrees at all, and should guide choices about the structure of individual programs.
Looking more broadly, however, these practical considerations are part of a bigger picture in 
terms of the institutional context for international joint and dual degrees. In qualitative fol-low-up, a number of respondents noted that collaborative degree programs are part of their 
institutions‚Äô efforts toward comprehensive internationalization, defined by ACE as a ‚Äústrate-
gic, coordinated process that seeks to align and integrate policies, programs, and initiatives to position colleges and universities as more globally oriented and internationally connected institutions.‚Äù ACE‚Äôs Center for Internationaliza

ore globally oriented and internationally connected institutions.‚Äù ACE‚Äôs Center for Internationalization and Global Engagement (CIGE) has devel-
oped a Model for Comprehensive Internationalization, illustrated in Figure 14, which is com-
posed of six interconnected pillars that require attention as institutions design strategies and create policies to advance internationalization; the ‚Äúcollaborations and partnerships‚Äù pillar includes JDDPs, among other academic ventures.

A key feature of the CIGE Model is that the six pillars are interconnected; often, progress in 
one area is dependent upon‚Äîand gives rise to‚Äîprogress in ot

are interconnected; often, progress in 
one area is dependent upon‚Äîand gives rise to‚Äîprogress in others. Related to joint and dual 
degrees, for example, tenure and promotion policies that reward (or at least, do not discourage) 
international activity and engagement may facilitate faculty involvement in and commitment to collaborative programs, and allow academic staff to prioritize this work over other projects. Student learning outcomes that include international knowledge and competencies may moti-
vate the development of JDDPs as a venue by which students can fulfill these educational 
objectives. A definitive message from top leadership about the importance of international academic collaboration, and its incorporation into institutional planning documents, may out-weigh objections by officials in the budget office. 
Conversely, however, a lack of attention to these and other areas of internationalization may 
hinder the development and implementation of international collaborat

s of internationalization may 
hinder the development and implementation of international collaborative degree programs. Decisions about whether and how to pursue these programs should take into account the overall state of internationalization on campus; if little progress has occurred, the CIGE 
Model can help institutions identify key policies, structures, and practices that need to be 
addressed in order to create a supportive environment for joint and dual degrees. Making sure this institutional groundwork is in place prior to program creation will increase the likelihood 
of successful, sustainable collaborations. 
Of course, this comprehensive approach adds yet another layer of complexity to the program 
development process‚Äîperhaps an unappealing prospect when potential partners overseas are calling, and the possibility of added tuition revenue looms large. The potential payoff, how -
ever, is great‚Äîwhen done well, the benefits of international collaborative degree programs exte

ow -
ever, is great‚Äîwhen done well, the benefits of international collaborative degree programs extend well beyond individual program participants and added revenue. By contributing to an institutional climate and ethos that foster global awareness by faculty, staff, and students, inter -
national joint and dual degrees can advance campus-wide internationalization efforts and help 
institutions fulfill their imperative to prepare students to live and work in the globalized world 
of the twenty-first century. Even more broadly, these programs contribute to a global flow of people, information, and ideas that‚Äîwe can hope‚Äîwill facilitate relationships and collabo-ration, build mutual understanding, and, ultimately, lead to a more interconnected, peaceful 
world.

CIGE InsightsAppendix: Methodology
In January 2014, an electronic survey was sent to contacts at 382 institutions that indicated in 
ACE‚Äôs 2011 Mapping Internationalization on U.S. Campuses Survey that the

itutions that indicated in 
ACE‚Äôs 2011 Mapping Internationalization on U.S. Campuses Survey that they offered or were 
in the process of developing international joint and/or dual degree programs at the time. Indi-
vidual contacts were identified based on who at the institution had completed the Mapping Survey, but the directions indicated that if necessary, the survey could be forwarded to another institution representative who would be better positioned to complete it.
A total of 134 institutions submitted valid survey responses, for an overall response rate of 35 
percent. All 134 respondents provided institution-level data about strategic planning and poli-cies for international joint and dual degree development and administration. 
In addition to institution-level data, the survey also requested information about individual 
international joint and dual degree programs administered by the institution. Respondents at 
89 of the 134 responding institutions provided data about specif

by the institution. Respondents at 
89 of the 134 responding institutions provided data about specific joint and/or dual degree programs at their institutions (the remaining 45 only provided the institution-level data). 
Institutions that administer more than one joint and/or dual degree program were asked to 
provide information about each individual program. Across the 89 institutions that provided 
program-level data, information was received on a total of 193 individual programs.
Survey respondents were asked if they would be willing to be contacted for follow-up; email 
correspondence and telephone interviews with key informants were used to gather additional 
information on themes that emerged from the survey data. Informants were asked to verify the 
accuracy of the written summaries of their contributions prior to publication of the report.

Abstract ‚Äî According to psychology, not everybody can excel at all kinds of tasks. Thus, chances of a 
successful outcome of software development increase if people with particular personality traits are 
assigned to their preferred tasks in the project. Li kewise, software development depends significantly on 
how software practitioners perform their tasks. This empirical study surveys 100 Cuban software 
developers, both students and profes sors of the University of Inform atics Sciences in Havana, Cuba. 
This work aims to find possible patterns that link personality traits to role preferences in a software life 
cycle. Among the various roles, system analyst, software d

s to role preferences in a software life 
cycle. Among the various roles, system analyst, software designer, and programmer are found to be the most preferred among the participants. In contrast, te ster and maintainer happen to be the least popular 
roles among software engineers. 
 
Index Terms ‚ÄîHuman factors in software engineering, Software life cycle, Human aspects of 
software development, Software psychology 
I. INTRODUCTION
 AND  BACKGROUND 
Software engineering has been one of the most prom inent professions over the last 20 years, and it is 
projected to evolve even further. Software engineering comprises stages in distinct areas, such as analysis, design, programming, testing, and maintenance. Today, specialties within software engineering are as diverse as in any other profes sion. Additionally, software engineers need to 
communicate more effectively with users and team members, thus the people dimension of software 
engineering is as important as technical expertise.  
So

ers, thus the people dimension of software 
engineering is as important as technical expertise.  
Software project managers have always faced the problem of assigning the tasks to the right people 
within a team in such a fashion that increases the ch ance of successful project completion [1]. Different 
ideas have been tried to use diverse ways to maximize performance [2] and make choices in the 
software engineering process [3]. Those ideas invol ve: motivation (software engineers tend to perform 
better if they are motivated to do specific tasks), the environment, and personality type, or a 
combination of these factors. Motivation and the environment are known to influence task performance. 
Motivation is generally a powerful element in the performance of task goals, especially in the IT field 
[4], [5]; however, motivation is often insufficien t for influencing performance of goals on its own. 
Similarly, environmental factors cannot independently generate the performance of tasks

on its own. 
Similarly, environmental factors cannot independently generate the performance of tasks. Hence, there 
are multiple factors involved in the performances of software engineers [6]. This study specifically investigates the role of individual preferences in software projects, while neglecting the elements of 
motivation and environment, which have been the focu s of most scholarly research on this topic. Feldt 
et al. [7] also state that environmental factors alone cannot improve task performance. Thus this work 
exclusively investigates the role of individual pref erences in software projects, focusing explicitly on 
how personality types affect preferences for specific software roles.  
Several studies investigate the relationship betwee n software engineer personalities and performance 
by identifying associations between particular personality types and specific tasks in software 
development. For example Choi [8] and Da Cunha [9 ] report specific issues related to progra

ftware 
development. For example Choi [8] and Da Cunha [9 ] report specific issues related to programming. 
Acuna and Juristo [10] introduce a capability-person re lationship model that can be used by software 
project managers to assign tasks to people based on soft skills. Acuna et al. [11] report that properly 
assigning people to development roles is crucial for creating productive teams, and their human capacity-based procedure can aid managers at small- to medium-sized software organizations.  
Ritcher and Dumke [12] adapt the Big Five method for software engineering with a Failure Mode and 
Effect Analysis method that models the human fact or as a risk factor in the software engineering 
process and examines methods to evaluate psychological characteristics to diagnose expected 
productivity. Capretz and Ahmed [13] present a bett er understanding of the general preferences of 
software engineers in software life cycle phases and map these phases to the Myers-Briggs Type 
Indicat

tware engineers in software life cycle phases and map these phases to the Myers-Briggs Type 
Indicator (MBTI) dimensions taking into consideration desi rable soft skills that appear in job ads. As far 
as these studies are concerned, not only performance and task choices are affected by personality type, 
but also other factors, such as motivation and th e surrounding environment, can influence task choice, 
motivation to carry out a task, and task performance.  
A wide variety of psychological instruments are us ed for career counseling and behavior prediction. 
In understanding the influence of personality on software development tasks there exists a wide variety 
of personality frameworks (e.g., Five-Factor theory, Keirsey Temperament Sorter, etc.). The MBTI [14] 
is one of the most popular tools used in workplac es to analyze personality types. According to the 
MBTI, a person is measured across four dimensions  by his/her preferences: energizing, attending, 
deciding, and living.

sured across four dimensions  by his/her preferences: energizing, attending, 
deciding, and living. 
Within each dimension, there are two opposite poles : Extroversion (E) ‚Äì Introversion (I), Sensing (S) 
‚Äì Intuition (N), Feeling (F) ‚Äì Thinking (T), and Percei ving (P) ‚Äì Judging (J). Sixteen distinct personality 
types are defined on the basis of combining these pr eferences; each type is denoted by four letters. 
These distinctions have an influence on career choi ce because people tend to choose occupations that 
are related to their personality type. 
Within the first dimension, Extroverts get their ener gy from interactions with people, are outgoing, 
and prefer to work with other people, whereas Introve rts get their energy internally and prefer to work 
alone.  Secondly, the S-N dimension is related to the way in which people acquire information. In 
particular, sensing people receive information from th eir five senses and are attuned to the practical, 
hands-on, common-sense ap

ive information from th eir five senses and are attuned to the practical, 
hands-on, common-sense approach to information; intuitive individuals are more focused on complex 
interactions, theoretical implications, and new possibil ities. The third dimension, T-F, is concerned with 
how people make decisions. Specifically, thinkers pref er to analyze logical/objective data. In contrast, 
feelers respond to situations depending on their feeli ngs about that situation and often want work that 
provides services to people. Finally, the Judging type  prefers work that has a need for order, whereas 
the Perceiving type prefers tasks that require adapting to changing situations.  
The MBTI has its critics [15] who point out shortc omings with its statistical structure and other 
limitations [16]. We should be cautious about its pos sible misuse in organizational and occupational 
settings. However, MBTI continues to be the most popular instrument used in profiling the personality 
types of so

ver, MBTI continues to be the most popular instrument used in profiling the personality 
types of software engineers [17].  
Myers [14] shows that an individual‚Äôs interest in jobs is mainly determined by the S-N and T-F 
dimensions. These pairs are responsible for the cognitive scales that influence the extent to which 
people feel attracted to and satisfied by their career c hoices: STs prefer activitie s that require the use of 
established knowledge and are observant and detail-orie ntated, they are reluctant to try new innovative 
solutions; NTs are creative and, consequently, enjo y symbolic abstract relations and seek to find 
patterns rather than dealing with details. Addition ally, they like to create new knowledge rather than 
applying or improving existing techniques. NTs are more  creative than STs because Ns see possibilities 
beyond the given facts and look for patterns and relati onships. Thus, when NTs join both theoretical 
frameworks with their tendency to extrapolate

relati onships. Thus, when NTs join both theoretical 
frameworks with their tendency to extrapolate beyond the details, they can identify new principles. The 
extroversion-introversion and judgment-percepti on dimensions determine individuals‚Äô personal 
attitudes.  
Most studies concerning the MBTI distribution among students and engineering professionals 
demonstrate that ISTJ, INTP, and ESTJ are over-repr esented personality types, whereas ENFJ and INFJ 
types are underrepresented [18]. The personality di stribution of computer application software 
engineers can be seen in Table I, which presents data taken from the book MBTI Type Tables for 
Occupations  [19] for Software Engineers, System Analysts, and Programmers. 
Cruz et al. [20] present a comprehensive systematic literature review of personality in software 
engineering. Other researchers have studied characteristics and traits in personality types for certain 
roles in software engineering [21], [22], [23], and [24]. System A

in personality types for certain 
roles in software engineering [21], [22], [23], and [24]. System Analysts and Programmers are among 
the more explored roles in these studies. Nevertheless, we do not find a straight relationship among their 
preferences and personality types. Since there is a logical relationship between the task preferences and 
proportions of personality types in software engineering, our study seeks to provide a precise 
configuration of relationships between personality type s, task preferences, and roles in order to obtain 
conclusive results. In particular, an empirically validated study of actual software developers is used to 
investigate these relationships.

Software engineers review, design, create, and te st software for basic computer applications, 
including operating systems, compilers, and computer networks. They expand existing or launch new general software applications and may also examine or design databases. They establish operational 
specifications and study requirements using comput er science, engineering, or mathematics. The 
software engineering discipline can be seen as an umbrella career f

ngineering, or mathematics. The 
software engineering discipline can be seen as an umbrella career for specialized tasks. 
 System analysts must be able to understand system essentials, and to create an abstract model of the 
application in which user needs are met. They also require a significant amount of interaction with 
users/clients to understand the scope and constraints of  the software solution, and to propose procedures 
to improve software capabilities and workflow.  
Software designers are responsible for modeling the proposed system as well as evaluating and 
validating the designed model to ensure its quality before generating the soft ware code. According to 
Shatnawi and Alzu‚Äôbi [26], unlike other engineering products software systems are not tangible. Due to 
their complexity, software quality assurance is essential to maintain its quality. Nevertheless, designers 
identify appropriate components by experimenting wi th a variety of schemes in order to discover the 
opt

ify appropriate components by experimenting wi th a variety of schemes in order to discover the 
optimal way of refining the application for the clie nt. Ideally, software designers should have sufficient 
skills for producing a model that supports the programmer activities and provides an accurate translation of the customer requirements into a fini shed software product that is stable and operates on 
real machines. 
Programmers transfer project specifications into detailed algorithms for coding into a computer 
language. They create and write computer programs to pe rform calculations and store, locate, or retrieve 
data or other information. The process of programmi ng requires the identification of control structures, 
relevant variables, and data structur es as well as a detailed understandi ng of the syntax and specifics of 
a programming language. In particular, programmers ne ed to attend to details and maintain an open, 
logical, analytical style. MBTI type distribution among

to attend to details and maintain an open, 
logical, analytical style. MBTI type distribution among computer programmers is also presented in 
Table I [19].  
The task of testing is focused on identifying faults; there are many ways to make testing efforts more 
efficient and effective. Testing strategies are neit her random nor haphazard; rather, they should be 
approached in a methodical and systematic manner. The process of debugging errors can be a 
frustrating and emotionally challenging activity that can lead software engineers to restructure their thinking and decisions. Takamatsu et al. [27] realize that software testing is costly. They recommend automated testing and consider it to be an effectiv e way to reduce the burden of testing. However, 
testing requires persistence, especially because of the need to choose from an enormous range of 
possibilities and maintain a high level of attention to detail. 
Software maintenance involves keeping applications  operational, reactin

el of attention to detail. 
Software maintenance involves keeping applications  operational, reacting qui ckly to problems when 
produced in order to restore service, meeting or exceeding the agreed level of service, and maintaining 
the confidence of the user community. Specifically, maintenance personnel should ensure that users believe in their support team as dedicated and competent individuals who are acting within the agreed budget. Unfortunately, we could not find data pr oviding MBTI type distribution among designers, 
testers, or maintainers to do comparisons with observed results. 
III. RESEARCH
 METHODOLOGY 
This paper aims to identify software engineers‚Äô  preferred roles on the basis of their distinct 
personality types. We have used an empirical met hod to relate personality types and preferences in 
software engineering roles. This constitutes an important link between personality types and tasks to 
which engineers are inclined. In order to understa nd whether individual

onality types and tasks to 
which engineers are inclined. In order to understa nd whether individual personality affects software 
engineers‚Äô performance, specific results from the field are required. Consequently, 100 software 
developers from the University of Informatics Scie nces (UCI) in Havana, Cuba, have been surveyed. 
For the sake of clarification, UCI is an atypical university, where both students and professors are directly engaged in software projects. Their average experience as software developers is five years. So 
it is correct to think of UCI students/professors as software practitioners, as they develop software 
products that are exported to several countries. 
In this study, 100 Cuban software developers were  surveyed, including students in senior Informatics 
Sciences Engineering courses and professors at the Un iversity of Informatics Sciences in Havana, Cuba. 
There were seven senior students and 93 professors among the subjects. Both students and professors 
we

re were seven senior students and 93 professors among the subjects. Both students and professors 
were directly involved in software development with an average experience of five years as software 
developers. So it is accurate to think of UCI students and professors as software practitioners. Actually, 
they develop software products that are exported  to several Latin American countries and a few 
European countries. They were invited to take part in the survey based on their willingness to do so. 
The sample contained 47% males and 53% females. It is  the country‚Äôs policy that all Cuban universities 
have a balanced ratio between males and females to avoid gender bias.  The student age range was 
between 22 and 23 years of age, while professors ranged from 23 to 27 years of age. The MBTI 
instrument, Form M, Spanish language version, was us ed to identify their personality types. Although 
this instrument is self-assessed, a CPP Certified evaluator was present and processed the dat

hough 
this instrument is self-assessed, a CPP Certified evaluator was present and processed the data.  
As far as the individual roles were concerned, prior to collecting this information about role 
preferences, the subjects were given the role defi nitions. The seven students in the sample acted as 
project leaders in international projects at the moment of the study. All the students had five years of experience as software practitioners at the time the survey was applied. On the other hand, professors in the sample had five to eight years of experience  in software development. Among them 30% were 
analysts, 28% programmers, 12% of the subjects had experience in testing and maintenance, 11% were 
designers, and the rest had been project leaders.  
After the MBTI was applied, participants were queried about their preferences for the various roles: 
analyst, designer, programmer, tester, and maintainer. Specifically, participants were asked to state if 
they preferred, did not prefe

er, and maintainer. Specifically, participants were asked to state if 
they preferred, did not prefer, or were neutral ab out these roles. In particular, participants were 
instructed to focus only on their overall preferences and to disregard any particular software 
development tasks that they might have been performing at the moment the research was conducted.

three times as common as feeling (25%), and judging people (61%) outnumber perceiving individuals (39%).

V. CONCLUSION 
An empirical study was conducted to map some oppos ing psychological traits, such as extroversion-
introversion, sensing-intuition, thinking-feeling, and judging-perceiving to the main tasks of a software 
life cycle. This work addresses the fundamental issue of the impact of human factors in software 
development. This research provides an empirical assessment of the relationships between software 
engineers‚Äô MBTI types and role preferences. Although the MBTI does not predict success in a 
particular career, it identifies individual preferences for specific occupations.  
The results indicated by the personality types INFJ, ISFP, INFP, ESFP, ENFP, ENTP, ESFJ, and 
ENFJ are not relevant because of the sample size. In each of these cases, our data values are in the range 
of one and three individuals, thus it lacks statistical significance.  0%20%40%60%80%100%

However, distinctive patterns are evident in the relationship between personality types and 
preferences of software engineering roles. This st udy revealed particular role preferences for each 
personality type. It has been inferred, with high si gnificance, that 84% ESTJs, 93% ESTPs, 80% ISTJs, 
86% ISFJs, 67% INTJs, 100% ESFPs, and 80% INTPs indicate analysis in their preferences. While 
76% ESTJs, 67 ESTPs, 71% ISFJs/ENTJs, 83% ISFJs, 67% ESFPs, a nd 100% ISTPs prefer 
programming. On the other hand, preferences for designing, testing, and maintenance are described 
according to the sample. It can be concluded th at assigning a person with specific psychological 
characteristics to tasks of the software life cycle be st suited for his/her traits increases the chances of a 
successful outcome for the project. 
Overall, the roles of analyst, designer, and programmer were the most popular roles among all 
personality types, whereas t

nalyst, designer, and programmer were the most popular roles among all 
personality types, whereas tester and maintainer were identified as the least desirable. The margins of neutral positions can be decreased through further i nquiries about software engineer preferences.  
Finally, it is important to point out that the st udy of the relations between personality types and 
software roles provides more light as to how software  development is affected based on individual type 
indicators and how important it is to match the right people to roles in software engineering.

What
Is
an
Extracurricular
Activity?
Before
we
provide
you
with
a
comprehensive
list
of
the
extracurricular
activities
you
can
choose
from,
it‚Äôs
essential
you
understand
what
an
extracurricular
activity
is
to
debunk
any
misconceptions
about
them!
Extracurriculars
are
activities
you
participate
in
outside
of
the
classroom.
While
some
can
center
around
academic
subjects,
they
are
not
part
of
schools‚Äô
curriculums
and
are
pursued
in
your
free
time.
The
majority
of
extracurricular
activities
in
high
school
in
are
found
and
engaged
in
at
their
school,
although
they
may
also
be
offered
through
other
institutions
within
your
community .
Extracurriculars
generally
differ
from
hobbies
because
they
are
more
formally
organized,
follow
schedules,
involve
other
students
and
teachers,
and
aim
to
foster
personal
growth,
skill
development,
and

Introduction  
 
  

How to Impress U.S. Universities  
2  
  
 
"Amid challenges, seeds of resilience grow into towers of achievement. For 
students dreaming of U.S. education, each hurdle is a testament to your strength, 
and each success is a triumph against all odds. From hardship to a future, 
shining in gold."  
Su Nge Aung (Ms)  
Education Advisor  
EducationUSA Burma  
This is a book about dreams.  We all have them -visions of what 
we want our life to look like.  Many times our families have dreams 
for us as well.  Sometimes th ey are shared and sometimes th ey are 
different than our own.  Your dreams probably contain ideas of 
what you would like to do for work and where you can get the 
education to reach that goal.  
If traveling to the United States in order to study is a part of 
that vision, then this book is for you.  It is meant to help you 
understand the U.S. educational system at the college or uni

k is for you.  It is meant to help you 
understand the U.S. educational system at the college or university 
level.  It is here to help you navigate the system and to understand 
what those universities are looking for when they review 
candidates.  It is also here to help you take full advantage of the 
experience that you could gain from studying in the U.S.  

Introduction  
3 A U.S. education is valued the world over, partly because it is 
different than other types of university education.  It is based on 
certain principles and traditions that serve students well  and that 
encourage a particular type of thinking and approach to the world.   
Multiple Paths  
A U.S. education can open doors of opportunity . For many 
students, it allows them to get the kind of preparation and 
credentials that they will need to return to their home country and 
make a difference.  Having completed a degree in the United States 
will help them stand out from any other candidates with whom they 
ma

a degree in the United States 
will help them stand out from any other candidates with whom they 
may have to compete.  It will demonstrate a high level of rigor, 
independent thinking, and problem -solving ability that allows 
individuals to lead others responsibly.  
For other students, a U.S. University education will lead to a 
path of working in the United States.  This often starts with an 
experience in O ptional Practical Training  (OPT)  that is approved 
on many student visas.  Students who are successful with this 
opportunity are sometimes given the chance to remain in the country as an employee of the company or another company with whom they are able to connect.  For some students, that starts the 
process of them becoming a long -term resident in the country.  
Still other students will leverage their experience to become true 
global citizens.  They will take their degree, and instead of returning 
to their home country, they may go to live and work anywhere around the

, and instead of returning 
to their home country, they may go to live and work anywhere around the globe.  In doing this, they are able to bring the diverse 
perspective from their education to their  work experience. 
How to Impress U.S. Universities  
4 The English Benefit  
Depending on where students are coming from, learning or 
mastering the English language may  be part of their journey.  Even 
students who have studied for many years in their home country 
will often find that speaking in the United States is quite different.  
Not only is colloquial English different than academic English, but 
American English is different from British or Australian English, 
and there are regional accents that can be a challenge to a nonnative 
speaker.  That said, there is no better way to learn  the language than 
to live it.  
Even with a relatively limited level of English, students can 
benefit from the total immersion that comes from studying at a U.S. College or university, rapidly i

benefit from the total immersion that comes from studying at a U.S. College or university, rapidly improving their speaking, listening, 
and reading abilities.  For many students, depending on their 
country of origin, this facility in English alone provides them with 
a major benefit in the job market.  It opens the door to multinational 
companies, government agencies, travel-oriented jobs, translation, 
teaching, and much more.  
The Social Benefit  
What many students do not think about in their calculations of 
whether or not to study in the United States are the social and cultural elements that can be beneficial.  It is very common for 
students who are attending a U.S. College or university to meet new 
friends that they will stay in touch with for their whole lives.  For 
example, my mother is 76 years old.  She made a friend while she 
was in college over 50 years ago from the country of Cyprus.  This 
Introduction  
5 summer she will travel there to visit her friend after ye

country of Cyprus.  This 
Introduction  
5 summer she will travel there to visit her friend after years of keeping 
in touch.   
The same thing happened to me.  I made  friends with a Japanese 
student while I was in college the 1990‚Äô s. Twenty years later I visited 
him in Japan. Recently, I  spoke with an international student on our 
campus who had made friends with an American student.  She 
accompanied the student to her home for the T hanksgiving holiday.  
The American family now treats the student, who is from Bangladesh, as another member of the family.  The parents call to 
check in with this student just like they do their own daughter.  
There are many stories of this type.  Despite the stereotypes, 
many Americans are very friendly and very curious about other 
cultures.  While they typically do not excel in learning foreign 
languages, this does not mean that they‚Äôre not interested in people 
from other places.  In fact, international students often find that 
Americans a

terested in people 
from other places.  In fact, international students often find that 
Americans are very open and transparent in their communication.  
They tend to say what they‚Äôre thinking and what they mean, rather than guarding information.  This makes it easy to form frien dships.   
American families, in particular, have a history of reaching out 
to students from other places and inviting them for meals or to celebrate holidays.  It doesn‚Äôt always happen all at once.  The United 
States tends to be a transactional culture, so there is much less 
emphasis on family ties.  At first, it may seem like American students 
are not willing to take the time to get to know you, but if you are 
persistent, and especially if you join in with them in the activities 
that they enjoy, you will find that you quickly become part of  their 
inner circle. 
It is not uncommon at my university for international students 
to return 10 or 20 years later to visit people who they met while 
How to Im

international students 
to return 10 or 20 years later to visit people who they met while 
How to Impress U.S. Universities  
6 they were on campus.  Sometimes they send their sons and 
daughters to study with us as well.  
The Cultural Benefit 
In general, the American culture has a strong sense of taking 
care of  one‚Äôs neighbors . Sometimes students are surprised to find 
that Americans are friendlier  to people they don‚Äôt know or have 
recently met than they seem to be to their own relations.  
International students often benefit from this welcome.  
The United States also tends to be a very casual culture.  
Students are surprised to find that peoplll each other by their first 
names.  Even younger people often use the first names of people 
much older than they are.  There is very little social stratification.  
While there is respect for people in authority, it is also acceptable to question in most situations.  
Many decisions are made through consensus or discussion that 
in

to question in most situations.  
Many decisions are made through consensus or discussion that 
in other countries would be made in a  top down fashion. This can 
be confusing and sometimes even frustrating for international 
students, because it can make the decision -making process slower.  
Still, this is a difference that international students can learn 
something from, as they see the unique combination of logic and 
persuasion that drives much of American interaction.  
The Geopolitical Benefit  
Students will also often be surprised to learn the way that 
Americans view themselves in the world.  In many countries, 
Americans are seen as overbearing.  This is particularly true in 
politics, where the United States is often viewed as aggressively 
Introduction  
7 getting involved in other regions.  This sometimes creates 
resentment.  Often when students come to United States to study, 
they receive a totally different view of the way Americans look at 
the world. 
I like to te

study, 
they receive a totally different view of the way Americans look at 
the world. 
I like to tell students that if they have seen western movies with 
cowboys in them, they have seen a bit of the American heart.  While 
many other places in the world view of America as meddling and 
overreaching, most Americans think of themselves as defenders of the weak.  Just like a cowboy, who rides into a western town and 
sees villains mistreating the local inhabitants, America often views itself as coming to the rescue of those who need its strength.   
What other countries often see as intimidation,  Americans tend 
to see as  role of the older brother looking out for younger siblings.  
Keeping this framework in mind can sometimes help in understanding why Americans behave the way that they do.   
Immerse Yourself  
If you come to United States to study, I highly encourage you 
to get out of just the university context, and especially to get out of the group of other students from your ho

f just the university context, and especially to get out of the group of other students from your home country.  You learn so 
much if you are able to connect with average Americans in the 
places that they live and work.  If you seem open to it, they will 
invite you to their homes, their churches, their civic events, and 
their entertainment.  They may not always know your cultural 
norms, but they will do everything they can to help you enjoy an American experience. 
If you are considering studying in the United States, I would 
highly encourage you to do so.  It will be a life -changing experience 
How to Impress U.S. Universities  
8 if you allowed to be.  Yes, achieving a U.S. degree is a powerful 
thing, and it will open doors to your future career.  At the same time, 
your experience can be so much more than just a degree if you are 
open to what you find when you arrive.   
Do not try to recreate your culture here, but bring the best of 
your culture and share it with people h

ot try to recreate your culture here, but bring the best of 
your culture and share it with people here who are curious.  Ask lots 
of questions, learn all you can, and invest in the relationships that 
you find.  These opportunities will pay you back many times over, 
and be even more valuable than the degree that you earn.  
In this book, I will do everything I can to help you achieve your 
dream.  
Take aways:  
‚ô¶ The goal of this book is to help you navigate the U.S. university application process and show you how to get the most value from a U.S. educational experience  
‚ô¶ A U.S. university education can lead you to multiple paths for your future  
‚ô¶ This experience offers many benefits, including: 
‚ô¶ Improving your English if it is not your native 
language  
‚ô¶ Rich opportunities for social connections  
‚ô¶ A chance to experience culture and learn from it 
‚ô¶ A better understanding of the role and identity of the 
U.S. in the world  
‚ô¶ To get the maximum benefit, it is essential no

f the role and identity of the 
U.S. in the world  
‚ô¶ To get the maximum benefit, it is essential not to 
attempt to recreate your home culture, but to fully 
immerse yourself in your host culture

Chapter 1

Advice from the Expert  
International students have been a milestone in shaping the US educational 
landscape. As complex as their situation is in their home countries; inflation, 
high exchange rate and lack of opportunities to make their profiles outstanding 
on their applications , students from North Africa prove to be successful and to 
have high rates of enrollment compared to years before. According to the Open 
Doors report of 2023, Tunisia as a case study witnessed an increase of 680 Tunisians studying in the US, compared to 534 in 2020. 61.8 of them attend 
doctoral universities (Data, 2023) .  
As a member of the Community- based organizations, my recommendation 
for students is to set objec

As a member of the Community- based organizations, my recommendation 
for students is to set objectives and targets since early stages of high school years to engage in cultural and extracurricular activities to build a strong personality 
and a growing interest in international education. To do this well, they should seize the chance to participate in exchange programs, not only to enhance their 
chances of admissions, but also to prepare themselves for a new cultural phase,  
which is becoming an international student.  
This new title comes with new responsibilities such as enduring 
homesickness, working on -campus to be financially comfortable, and enhancing 
their experiential learning to apply the skills they learned to their job.  
International students are an asset to overseas universities. They will be bearers 

My Experience  
11 and ambassadors of their culture. It is not an added number to the student 
population, it is a new flag on campus, a new activity in the office

an added number to the student 
population, it is a new flag on campus, a new activity in the office of Global Engagement, more activities in the International Education Week and more 
fun in the classroom. However , to implement this, students need to reach out to 
experts in the field, build connections with admissions officers and visit schools; 
in-person or virtually to find out their passions early- on. 
Today‚Äôs student is tomorrow‚Äôs leader  
Ilhem Daadaa  
EducationUSA Advisor  
Amideast Tunisia  
Let me start by telling you a little about my background in 
higher education and in international education in particular.  
When I graduated from high school in the United States, I 
applied to become an exchange student with Rotary International.  
I spent a year in between high school and college studying in Argentina.  I attended school, I lived with two host families, and I 
completed an internship in a bank.  I learned a second language, and 
I made  the very most of my experien

ted an internship in a bank.  I learned a second language, and 
I made  the very most of my experience in a place that started out 
as very foreign to me. 
When I returned  to the United States, I attended college on a 
full scholarship to study international relations.  I completed my 
degree and began my study at the graduate level in Latin American

Institutional Types  
There are several major categories of institutions to be aware of.  
There are  private resear

pes  
There are several major categories of institutions to be aware of.  
There are  private research universities with a  national and 
international reach, there are large,  state-run public universities that 
also have a national  and international  audience.  Typically, each state 
has one of these primary public universities, but some have more.  
In addition , there are many private colleges and universities that 
would be considered regional.  This means that they tend to draw 
students from smaller geographic area.  Typically, they also have a 
stronger focus on teaching and less focus on research.  They often 
do not have as much name recognition as the large private institutions, but they offer students some very positive benefits, 
including smaller class sizes and classes taught by full faculty instead 
of graduate students.

The Liberal Arts  
One of the biggest misunderstandings that many international 
students have when they come to the U.S. to receive a degree is the 
American emphasis on a liberal arts education.  Even though only 
some colleges are considered in the liberal arts category, the whole foundation of U.S. higher education at the bachelors level is structured around the basic concepts of the liberal arts.  This can be 
frustrating for students coming from highly specialized fields.   
A student coming to study computer science may not 
understand why he or she is being asked take a course in English, 
philosophy , psychology, or history.  To this student, these classes 
may seem like a waste of time.  But the American higher education 
system has resisted the pull of hyper specialization.  Instead, it  is 
based in the concept that students should not only be excellent 
To Make a Great Impression, Understand the System  
23 technic

tudents should not only be excellent 
To Make a Great Impression, Understand the System  
23 technicians, they should also be well-rounded people who are able 
to think independently and act creatively.  
In its simplest form, I like to think about the liberal arts as a 
philosophy of leadership development.  The liberal arts sit on a base 
of education that was developed in England, and its roots go deep into classical western thought.  When colleges were founded in the 
United States in its early days, many of them were started outside 
of the major cities in smaller growing areas.  These areas ha d a 
desperate need for citizens who could  become leaders in their 
geographic region.  It was too far for them to travel to major cities 
for education, so smaller liberal arts colleges were founded to fill this need.   
These colleges were designed to train the kinds  of leaders that 
these smaller communities were desperate to find . This included 
lawyers, doctors, and clergymen in par

e smaller communities were desperate to find . This included 
lawyers, doctors, and clergymen in particular.  Students who 
attended these institutions were groomed, not to do a job, but be 
able to cross lines between jobs and lead people.  The basis of the 
liberal arts to this day is grounded in the ability of students to think 
broadly and learn from their history so that they can influence 
people, lead people, manage people, direct people, and  understand 
people.  A good way to think about this, is that the liberal arts does 
not focus on training students for a first job, but for a long-term career that will guide them to levels of leadership and management 
within organizations.  
Colleges and universities approach this tradition in different 
ways.  The most common form  that you may encounter it is a core 
curriculum or distribution requirement that all students are required to take at the institution regardless of their major.  This can be very 
confusing for international

o take at the institution regardless of their major.  This can be very 
confusing for international students.  Many of them are used to

United States and suddenly they are taking classes from lots of 
different areas of study.  But this is part of the philosophy of U.S. 
higher education.  The goal is to give students the broader view of 
the world, and to help them understand better how people think and interact with each other.  
It is a very different philosophy than many students are used to, 
but the results speak for themselves.  So, do  not be surprised if you 
arrive and find that only a few classes each semester are in your 
major, at least at the beginning.  Make the best possible use of these 
classes.  Enjoy them.  It is a great way to meet students from other 
majors and to learn about different viewpoints.

Religion and higher education  
Many international students are also confused by the historical 
connections of many colleges and universities to religious organizations.  The truth is, that almost every private college and 
university, even places like Harvard and Yale, at one point began as 
religious institutions.  The Christian church in America  was the 
primary founder of much of higher education, and many 
institutions were started, in whole or in part, to train clergy 
members for churches.  
For many colleges and universities, this religious tie is only in 
their distant history.  Most have become completely, or mostly , 
secular institutions.  If you see a religious connection in a 
university‚Äôs history, for example on its seal or motto, this does not mean that  you will encounter a religious environment.  For many 
institutions this is only part of their history.

Higher education in the United States began to change

demand for higher education rose dramatically in the United States 
at this time , partly because the government assisted sol

on rose dramatically in the United States 
at this time , partly because the government assisted soldiers coming

state institutions evolved from primarily teaching colleges to more

became  more selective, and people started comparing them to one

stronger part of university life.  This is really when the modern age

Since that time, higher education in the U.S. has undergone

some, however, particularly small and medium sized institutions,

Demonstrated Interest  
Many colleges and universities apply the concept of 
‚Äúdemonstrated interes t,‚Äù either officially or unofficially . 
Demonstrated interest means that a student has done something to indicate to the university that there is a high likelihood that the 
student will enroll if admitted. Why is this important?  
In the United  States, colleges are considered more prestigious  if 
they have many applicants but can only accept a small number. This 
is called the ‚Äúadmit rate.‚Äù The most prestigious colleges (like the Ivy League institutions) are considered so partly because the 
demand for them is high, so they have to turn away many students. That means that their admit rates or a cceptance rates are extremely 
low, sometimes in the single digits. Because of this focus on selectivity, colleges do not want to ‚Äú

low, sometimes in the single digits. Because of this focus on selectivity, colleges do not want to ‚Äúgive away‚Äù thei r acceptances to 
students with a low likelihood of attending. This means that if you 
are seen as a student who is applying to many, many universities, 
with no loyalty to any, you are less likely to receive an admission offer. Universities want to be your f avorite. They want to know that 
if you are admitted, you are likely to attend.

41 How Not to Communicate  
It is important to understand that admissions officers who work 
with international students face many specific challenges that tend 
to make them hesitate to communicate too much. First, they often 
receive a high volume of messages. Many of these messages ask the 
same questions over and over again. They have all had experiences with students who falsify their documents or misrepresent 
themselves. They have worked with students who are manipulative 
or even just rude. There is also a lot of room for cultural misunderstanding. Because of all of these elements, many 
admissions representatives are cautious in their communication.  
It is important to keep this in mind when you interact with 
admissions office. First, always be polite. This is so basic I should 
not even have to say it, but it is that important. Second, do not 
demand, request. The U.S. is a m

not even have to say it, but it is that important. Second, do not 
demand, request. The U.S. is a more egalitarian society, whi ch 
means that there is less difference than in some cultures between those with high- level authority and lower -level employees. All 
employees expect to be treated with a certain level of respect. It is also a culture that is skeptical of privilege. Unlike in many countries, being from a wealthy family or a high social group does not 
necessarily gain you respect or advantages. Respect is typically 
earned through your actions, so being too showy with wealth or social status can sometimes work against you.  
On the other hand, it is important not to come across as 
desperate. While admissions officers are typically sympathetic people, there is a point at which dramatic stories begin to be a 
negative. I also strongly advise against make an early appeal for a 
large amount of funding. We receive many message s each year that

42 Why is this a problem?  
Full scholarships in the current environment are quite rare. 
There was a time a few decades ago when colleges and universities 
operated with a philosophy that if they provided large scholarships 
to a few of the brightest stars, it would draw many other goo d 
students. After a few decades of experimentation, they found that 
this was typically not true. Instead, they found that by spreading 
their scholarship dollars over more students, they were better able to impact the quality of their student bodies as a wh ole. Because of 
this, it is much more common now for institutions to give smaller amounts of scholarship to larger numbers of students.  
At the same time, it is important to realize that while colleges 
and universities are considered non -profit organizations, they have 
bills

ize that while colleges 
and universities are considered non -profit organizations, they have 
bills to pay. Because of the high costs of the services they provide, most institutions need the money from tuition and fee s to pay a 
large portion of their costs. If they were to provide many large 
scholarships, they would be effectively paying the students to 
attend. That is just not a reasonable thing to ask of most universities.  
So, approaching with a request for full funding is likely to be 
received negatively by most institutions. I will not say never say it, that may be your only option, but that is certainly not the way to 
start a conversation.  
Sometimes, I think it is helpful to remember that most colleges 
look at this as building a life -long relationship with students. They 
want you to attend, contribute, and give back. You would not likely 
start a relationship by saying, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go to dinner together. You are paying.‚Äù That might seem extreme, but it is how the request

Recommendations are one of the most frequently overlooked 
opportunities to strengthen your application. Students often think that because most recommendations are positive, reviewers do not give them much credence. This is not necessarily the case. While i t 
is true that many letters of recommendation sound the same, that makes the ones that are unique stick out all the more.  In reading 
recommendations, I find that students typically make a few common mistakes:

recommenders about their background.

or career choices.

When I work with domestic students, I will often encourage 
them to write about a national or international issue. Do they have an opinion on something of global consequence? How does that 
subject impact them personally? How did they arrive at their 
opinion?

but it can also be a dangerous one. Your opinion is likely to be very different than many American students because of the lens of your experience, which is amazing in the classroom. In your  essay, 
however, it can be easy to strongly state an opinion that is either offensive to the person reading it, or which shows limited cultural understanding. For this reason, I would never choose a topic that revolved around American politics or its role in the world.  Similarly, 
I would probably not choose a religious topic, or something that spoke against other countries. While we would hope that an essay reader would be objective, we are all human and have our biases. It 
is too easy to let them influence us.  
So, now that we have looked at what not to write, how do we 
find a topic that will serve you well?

Essay Style and Content  
One of the more challenging aspects of writing a good essay if 
you are a stranger to American culture is getting your tone correct. Tone is the voice that you write in. Is it friendly, informative, sympathetic, persuasive? What emotion are you trying to co nvey to 
the reader? What are you hoping they will feel?  
I typically counsel students to use the tone that is most true

What are you hoping they will feel?  
I typically counsel students to use the tone that is most true to 
their personality. A humorous, fun tone can be excellent if that is 
your personality. It can give your reader a pleasant break from more 
serious essays that take up most of their day, but I would only recommend this if it is actually you. If you are fun, write fun, but if humor does not come that naturally to you, do not attempt it. If 
you are serious, factual, and understated, write that way. It will 
reinforce what you say about yourself and  the picture you are trying 
to create. If you are not sure what type of person you are, ask 
friends or family for their feedback. What is your strength? How do 
people typically react to you? How do you make them feel? Allow that best part of your personali ty to come across in what you write.  
It may seem obvious, but you need to make sure that you have

The most important tip: do not put the name of the wrong

I would avoid using the name at all , or have it checked very carefully 
to make sure that the right essay is going to the right place. American universities are strangely sensitive about finding a sense of loyalty with their students, and this will definitely trigger a 
negative reaction.  
The Goal  
While your essay is not the be all and end all of your application,

the English language, which will reassure the reader that you w ill be

collect your thoughts. Most admissions offices have pleasant 
waiting areas for you to relax ahead of your interview, s o arriving

Most schools of thought divide language learning into four 
main skills: speaking, writing, listening, and reading. Speaking and writing are considered active skills, while listening and reading are considered passive. When I look at traditional language le arning, 
the heavy emphasis is typically on the passive skills. We learn from written materials or by listening to audio materials. This is also the case in many language programs to which you might subscribe. 
They are mostly based on listening and reading.

your brain has to actively engage with it. It needs to practice rapid recall. It needs to have the opportunity to bend and manipulate the language to get a point across.  
The problem is that providing active learning for students is 
hard. It is much more labor -intensive than providing passive 
content that language learners can consume en masse . With active

The Certificate of Finance  
Universities collect financial information in one of two ways, 
they either require it at the point of application or they ask for it 
after admission, but before issuing visa documentation. Most institutions will utilize some form of Certificate of Finance (COF) 
document, in which the family commits to pay for the student‚Äôs expenses and indicates the sources. Sometimes these documents are 
also called Declaration of Finance documents. Families then 
typically have to provide bank statements that demonstrate th at 
they have sufficient funds in a way that can be easily accessed. 
Typically, these bank statements mu st be recent (typically within 90 
days). Some institutions require that there be

ank statements mu st be recent (typically within 90 
days). Some institutions require that there be an official conversion to dollars, others do not. Sometimes universities will accept notarized letters from an accountant confirming the funds.  
Certificate of Finance documents are often very confusing for 
families, even though many universities work hard to clarify them. The certificate of finance is basically a contract -like document that 
the student and the student‚Äôs sponsor (often parents) sign that 
indicates that the student understand s the cost of the education and 
how much the family will be expected to pay. The student and 
sponsor(s) indicate that they have the ability to pay this amount and 
are committed to doing so.  
One of the elements of this document that confuses people 
most is that it includes not only the  actual amount that families owe 
to the university (called direct costs or direct charges ), but also 
additional expenses that the student is likely to inc

ed direct costs or direct charges ), but also 
additional expenses that the student is likely to incur by studying 
Make a Great Impression by Your Approach to Finances  
101 international. This is often surprising to families. They have 
typically agreed to a certain price based on the tuition, housing, and meals and any scholarship funding the student receives. When they 
see the Certificate of Finance, the total number is higher. This is 
because the federal government requires that families be able to support their students for all of their educational expenses, not just 
those paid directly to the institution.  
The indirect costs include things like an assumed amount for 
travel and estimates for insurance, books, and miscellaneous living expenses that the student is likely to need. This makes sense if se en 
from the government ‚Äôs point of view. If the student budgets only 
enough to pay for their tuition and housing, what happens when they need to buy books? What happens if the

to pay for their tuition and housing, what happens when they need to buy books? What happens if they need to go to the 
pharmacy? The government is making sure that families do not budget the bare minimum and then end up short, with the institution or federal agencies having to either help the student or 
send them home.  
So, do not be surprised if the amount is different on the 
Certificate of Finance. You will not be directly charged for all of 
the indirect items. The U.S. government is helping  you to have a 
transparent view of what  the educational experience will really cost, 
so that no one can advertise a low price but then leave students in a difficult situation.

103 Student Work  
International students often have questions about working in 
the U.S. while on a visa. There is also a lot of mythology about what 
is possible. With just a few exceptions, students on an F- 1 visa are 
not allowed to work outside of campus. Students can some times 
apply for a financial hardship exception, but typically only after they have been enrolled for a year, and only if they can prove that 
economic conditions in their home country have deteriorated 
significantly during that time. There is also a cost fo r applying, so 
this is not an easy option.  
Students are also sometimes able to use their Curricular 
Practical Training (CPT) to work off campus. But, again, there are significant caveats. I t is typically only permissible after the first year, 
has to be directly related to your course of study, and may impact how long you are eligible to work after you complete your study.  
For most students, the best option is to work on campus.

great opportunity to build your work experience, improve your 
resume, and meet people. Being able to say you not only studied, but actually worked in another culture can be a strong advantage 
for you with future employers.  
Most universities have an officer with staff members who 
manage student work opportunities. Domestic students sometimes qualified for Federal Work Study, which are work opportunities 
that students receive based on their need, and for which the 
national government provides some of the funding. Institutional 
work  study on the other hand is typically open to all students,

apartment or dorm room and travel expenses). Therefore, you should expect to arrive in the US with plenty of funding for your real life ‚Äì  not just your studies.

LSAT or GMAT). Preparing for and performing well on these exams can give the admissions team one of many pieces of

Frequently Asked Question  
Why do I have to take classes that are not in my major? 
One of the bigge

requently Asked Question  
Why do I have to take classes that are not in my major? 
One of the biggest surprised that many international students 
find upon arriving at a U.S. college is that their academic schedules 
are partially filled with courses outside their major. This is 
particularly surprising for students who come from systems wh ere 
they have spent the last few years specializing in their studies. A 
computer science major who finds himself taking courses in 
history, psychology, or communications may feel like he is moving backwards.  
Most four- year institutions have what is called a ‚Äúgeneral 
education‚Äù requirement. This is a core of courses that all of their students take. Usually, this general education is built around what is called a ‚Äúdistribution requirement.‚Äù This means that stude nts are 
required to take a certain number of courses in different areas, but they often have the choice of which exact class. For example, you might be required to take two courses in

ften have the choice of which exact class. For example, you might be required to take two courses in social sciences, but you 
may be able to choose whether those courses are from areas like 
psychology, sociology, history, or other areas.  
Why is this required? As you know, higher education in the 
United States is respected worldwide for the way it prepares 
Making the Most of Your Experience  
125 students, and one of the primary differentiators of the American 
system is its liberal arts basis. This means that universities are not focused only on preparing students for getting a first job, but on 
preparing them for careers in leadership. The easiest way to think 
about liberal arts education is to think of it as leadership training.  
In the 1700‚Äôs and 1800‚Äôs, when most of the colleges in the 
United States began, many were founded in rural areas. They were 
started because these areas needed leaders. It was these colleges that produced the doctors, lawyers, and religious leaders

reas needed leaders. It was these colleges that produced the doctors, lawyers, and religious leaders that would 
serve these areas. Because of this dynamic, much of American 
higher education became focused on teaching students to lead people. This meant a focus on strong communication skills, the 
ability to influence people, management and leadership 
development. Over time, institutions have added more technical 
and career -oriented programs, but this sense of leadership 
development remains at the heart of much of American higher 
education, and is part of what makes it so special.  
So, if you arrive on campus and find that you have classes in 
areas that you did not anticipate, do not panic, and do not feel like someone has made a mistake. Consider these classes as an 
opportunity to develop your leadership skill and enjoy them! They will help you build your people skills and prepare you to be a more 
senior professional.

Title: The Valuable Lesson from My First Academic Setback
